something we found a gap in when we

we were just sort of accepting terms

for evaluating language you can find the

community repository under the working
group
naming's documents we do intend it to be
something
that people can use and people can share
um
but we broke it down into three sections
uh the first were what we called first
order concerns
um the second and third order concerns
as well
um so the first sort of concerns were
language where harm was egregious
overt and very clearly problematic um
second order concerns were language were
which was problematic but had a
less definite impact and third order
concerns were language that could use
improvement but
weren't doing demonstratable harm
so you have a set of questions for each
of these orders of concerns
and our our use case is that you
have a term under evaluation and you run
through the set of questions
for the term um the more yeses you have
the more likely it is something that you
need to consider changing
but the concerns are categorized for a
reason
and that reason is that first order
concerns are significantly
more harmful than third order concerns
so even if you only have one first order
concern that you've checked yes to and
nothing else is a yes we would still
recommend
putting more weight to those first order
concerns and slightly more weight to
those second order concerns
and running the evaluation that way um
we are intentionally non-prescriptive
in um in how many yeses or no's you
might need from
first or second or third order concerns
because we don't want this to become
a system that can be gained and we don't
want it to become
a rigid rubric that's never going to
work for language
so really it's a set of questions to ask
yourself about a term
um and as a general rule the more
guesses you have
more harm the term may be doing but
there are
some harm is more important than others
so um let's run through those concerns
really quickly uh and we'll we'll give a
few examples for each okay
so first order concerns are
characterized by being overt
um regardless of the context whether it
is technological or non-technological
these are
terms which clearly imbue harm
the second thing that first order
concerns are kind of characterized by
is they are very specific to an identity
so you can attach
there's meaning in the term that is very
specific
to specific people um
and the questions we ask ourselves to
clarify um
whether something is harmful in a first
order concern
way is if the term is overtly racist if
it is overtly sexist transphobic or
pejorative about a gender identity
if it is overtly ableist pejorative or
too nervous this is that to neurodiverse
or disabled people and if the term is
overtly homophobic
um so a really good example of a first
order concern is master slave
where while master potentially has other
connotations
slave is very clearly racist
particularly in an american context
and while kubernetes is an international
community
many of us are based in america and in
an american context
a slave means a black person so for us
this is a first order concern that we
are answering a huge affirmative to
and something that we feel very strongly
that we need to address within the
community
um so
second order concerns are things that
are harmful
but they're a little less specific um
and these are characterized in two ways
typically by a bit more ambiguity in
terms of language and a
lack of of specific identity
so in terms of ambiguity um within
code and in within some contexts
outside of code and technology this term
may not be harmful it's sort of
a merriam's dictionary definition thing
where one of the definitions may be a
harmful definition but the others are
not as bad and it's hard to say
what uh what the connotation truly is um
and the other is lack of a specific
identity in this regards
so whereas um first order concerns
were is this racist is this sexist
is this x is this y um we can't really
do the same
um for second order concerns so the two
terms were the two things we asked
ourselves for second order concerns
are whether the term is violent and
whether the term is militaristic
um so a good example of a violent term
would be kill commands in the unix
system where
it's clearly violent it's not violent
towards anyone in specific
um and within unix a kill command has a
very specific sort of
meaning um of
sort of terminating your process very
suddenly um
this has the the potential to make

um but we can't say specifically whom
um another example of this might be

there are many uses of the term master
which are not directly
about slave owning
but there's enough ambiguity in that

and so therefore within our framework
this is still something we would flag as
a yes
so third order concerns are things which
are not necessarily harmful in any way
um but they could still use improvement
and these are typically
around the actual language itself
so is the language clear is this the
clearest term we could use
um are we making things
uh seem human that aren't human or
anthropomorphizing them is what we call

um and is the term idiomatic and an
idiom is typically something that
wouldn't translate very well to another
language because it has very specific
cultural connotations
um so the two terms or the two questions
that we uh think of in this regards are
is the term evocative rather than

um and petsat versus staple set is a

pet set has meaning to us emotionally

and from a writing perspective from a

we want the descriptive name because

regardless of somebody's cultural
